name: Kendrick Lamar
description:
'''Kendrick Lamar Duckworth''' (born June 17, 1987) is an American rapper, singer, songwriter and record producer. Regarded as one of the greatest rappers of all time, he was awarded the 2018 [[Pulitzer Prize for Music]], becoming the first musician outside of the [[Classical music|classical]] and [[jazz]] genres to receive the award. Lamar's music, rooted in [[West Coast hip-hop]], features [[conscious rap|conscious]], introspective lyrics, with [[political criticism]] and [[social commentary]] concerning [[African-American culture]].

Lamar, born in [[Compton, California]], began releasing music under the stage name '''K.Dot''' in high school. He signed with [[Top Dawg Entertainment]] (TDE) in 2005 and co-founded the hip hop [[Supergroup (music)|supergroup]] [[Black Hippy]]. His [[Alternative hip hop|alternative rap]] debut album, ''[[Section.80]]'', leading to a joint contract with [[Dr. Dre]]'s [[Aftermath Entertainment]] and [[Interscope Records]]. He rose to fame with his [[gangsta rap]]-influenced second album ''[[Good Kid, M.A.A.D City]]'' (2012), which became the [[Billboard 200#Most weeks on the chart|longest-charting hip hop studio album]] on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and was named the greatest [[concept album]] of all time by ''[[Rolling Stone]]''. In 2015, he had his first [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] number-one single, with the remix of [[Taylor Swift]]'s "[[Bad Blood (Taylor Swift song)|Bad Blood]]", and released his third album, ''[[To Pimp a Butterfly]]'' (2015), which infused hip-hop with historical [[African-American music]] genres such as [[jazz]], [[funk]], and [[soul music|soul]], his first of six consecutive number-one albums on the ''Billboard'' 200.

Lamar's critical and commercial success continued with his [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[Pop music|pop]] album ''[[Damn (album)|Damn]]'' (2017), featuring his second US number one single, "[[Humble (song)|Humble]]". He contributed to the [[Black Panther: The Album|soundtrack]] of the 2018 film ''[[Black Panther (film)|Black Panther]]'', earning a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]] for "[[All the Stars]]". His fifth album ''[[Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers]]'' (2022), delved into introspection and concluded his tenure with TDE and Aftermath. In 2024, his [[Drakeâ€“Kendrick Lamar feud|feud]] with [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] led to his sixth album ''[[GNX (album)|GNX]]'' (2024), which included the chart-topping singles "[[Like That (Future, Metro Boomin and Kendrick Lamar song)|Like That]]", "[[Not Like Us]]", "[[Squabble Up]]" and "[[Luther (Kendrick Lamar song)|Luther]]" with the second winning five [[Grammy Awards]], including [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]], and the latter becoming his longest-charting number one song on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, at 13 weeks.

[[List of awards and nominations received by Kendrick Lamar|His accolades]], include 22 Grammy Awards ([[Grammy Award milestones#Most Grammys won by a rapper|the third-most won by a rapper]]), a [[Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Award]], a [[Brit Awards|Brit Award]], five [[American Music Awards]], seven [[Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], eleven [[MTV Video Music Awards]] (including 2 [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]] wins), and a record 37 [[BET Hip Hop Awards]]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' listed him as one of the [[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]] in 2016. Three of his works were included in ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s 2020 revision of the [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|500 Greatest Albums of All Time]]. Outside of music, Lamar co-founded the creative company [[PGLang]] and ventured into film with his longtime creative partner, [[Dave Free]].
